executive_summary: Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu (BJJ) studios have enjoyed modest growth over the past five years. The outbreak of COVID-19 hammered BJJ studios. Social distancing measures prevented BJJ studios from practicing because of the hands-on nature of the sport. Following the reopening of the economy and vaccine rollouts, pent-up demand led to solid growth in 2021. Still, BJJ studios did not fully recover because of the difficulty in gaining back customers they had lost. Nonetheless, growth in total recreation expenditure enabled BJJ studios to recover over the current period.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Outbreak of COVID-19 Hammered Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu (BJJ) Studios
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: BJJ studios faced considerable declines in 2020 as lockdown mandates fully shut BJJ studios for much of the year. Social distancing measures made in-person group classes impossible because of the hands-on nature of BJJ.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Various Factors Led to a Modest Recovery
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Pent-up demand following the reopening of the economy and vaccine rollouts led to considerable growth for BJJ studios in 2021, though not fully recovering from pandemic-induced lows as some studios faced difficulties gaining back customers they lost.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Growth will accelerate over the next five years for BJJ studios
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Considerable expansion in total recreation expenditure over the next five years will prop up the performance of BJJ studios. Climbing disposable income levels will bolster growth and induce consumers to take more expensive personal training sessions, potentially benefitting profit. Franchising is expected to increase over the next five years as franchises like 10th Planet Jiu-Jitsu have gained success.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Greater Visibility And Consumer Health Will Contribute To Expansion
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Continued strong growth in total recreation spending over the next five years will bolster the performance of Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu (BJJ) studios. The growth of mixed martial arts (MMA) and the Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC) will continue to garner new consumer interest in BJJ.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: F R A N C H I S I N G  T O  C O N T I N U E  T O  I N C R E A S E
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: A select few BJJ schools have gained success in franchising in recent years. 10 Planet Jiu-Jitsu has over 100 schools worldwide and has had this success because the brand name ensures that instructors have considerable skills.

industry_definition: Studios offer instruction in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu (BJJ), self-defense combat and martial arts sport to groups or individuals. BJJ emphasizes ground fighting and involves grappling, legwork, mounting and submissions. Studios also sell merchandise and sports-related equipment.

negative_impact_factors: low - increasing Barriers To Entry Level

threats: Time spent on leisure and sports

key_trends: The outbreak of COVID-19 led to considerable declines. Social distancing measures made in-person Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu (BJJ) group classes impossible. Some studios began offering classes online to offset some declines.

Growth will ramp up over the outlook period. Strong growth in disposable income will increase the number of consumers taking more expensive private training sessions. Surging total recreation expenditure will also promote growth.

Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu (BJJ) studios receive little public assistance. Private associations like the International Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu Federation and the American Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu Federation assist BJJ studios by hosting competitions, offering seminars and providing certifications.
Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu (BJJ) studios don't face industry-specific regulations. BJJ studios must obtain business licenses, abide by safety standards and follow insurance requirements.
Group training sessions bolster Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu (BJJ) studios. The cost, need for training partners and the social aspect of group training sessions contribute to growth in this segment.

Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu (BJJ) is becoming more popular among consumers aged 18 and younger. Kids-focused classes and the focus on teaching smaller individuals to defend themselves against larger individuals have spurred growth in this market.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market comprises consumers under the age of 18. BJJ studios have dedicated classes for children, contributing to this market comprising a considerable share of revenue.

While it has been commonplace for children to take martial arts classes for self-defense for quite some time, children primarily practiced Karate and Taekwondo. BJJ has become a more popular martial art than other arts as it focuses on teaching smaller individuals to defend themselves against larger individuals, contributing to strong growth among children.

Potential injury dissuades some consumers aged 35 to 49 from practicing BJJ. Also, consumers in this age range are often busy with their careers and family obligations, contributing to a smaller share of revenue than older demographics.
Potential injury and other health concerns contribute to this market, comprising the smallest revenue share.

products_and_services.product_description: Group training within Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu (BJJ) involves organized classes or sessions where a range of practitioners, spanning from novices to more experienced students, practice collectively under the supervision of an instructor.

Private instruction in BJJ comprises individualized, one-on-one sessions involving a BJJ practitioner and an instructor. Private training often focuses on students' weaknesses to help them improve their game.

Other products comprise merchandise and other sport-related equipment. BJJ studios often sell gis, rashguards, shorts, t-shirts, bumper stickers and other items with the studio's logo on them to their students.

tier_1_suppliers: Sporting Goods Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Sporting Goods Stores in the US
Athletic & Sporting Goods Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Mixed Martial Arts Studios in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: PRICE AND SOCIAL ASPECTS CONTRIBUTE TO GROUP TRAINING COMPRISING THE LARGEST MARKET
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The need for training partners is one of the primary reasons group training in BJJ is so popular. Also, group training is often much less expensive than private training. The social aspect of training in a group also encourages expenditure on this segment.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: THE PRICE OF PRIVATE TRAINING BOLSTERS THIS SEGMENT
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Private training is often much more expensive than paying a studio monthly for group classes, pushing up the segment's share of revenue. Consumers looking to improve their BJJ skills are often willing to pay a premium for these services.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: A SENSE OF BELONGING PUSHES UP THE SALE OF OTHER PRODUCTS
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Customers will often purchase merchandise and other sport-related equipment for a sense of community at their gym and to support the owner. Also, the sport-related equipment is often high quality as they are customized.

basis_points.basis_description: Other martial arts like boxing and karate are substitutes for BJJ. Also, exercise classes, like spin classes, are a source of external competition.

Brazilian jiu-jitsu (BJJ) studios face moderate buyer and supplier power. Buyers' ability to compare prices and instructors' reputations is strong. The price and breadth of coverage insurance companies will provide are their strongest sources of supplier power.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Market share concentration is low among Brazilian jiu-jitsu (BJJ) studios. Most BJJ studios are nonemployers, limiting the potential accumulation of considerable market share. Some franchises have found success, which may increase concentration.

Differentiation is the primary barrier to entry. Start-up costs are moderate, legal hurdles are low and many studios are nonemployers, but it may be difficult to attract students if an established studio exists in an area.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit has dipped because of the need for skilled workers
Brazilian jiu-jitsu (BJJ) studios have faced climbing rental costs

volatility_points.volatility_title: TOTAL RECREATION EXPENDITURE HAS INDUCED VOLATILITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: Given that Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu (BJJ) is considered a form of recreation, total recreation expenditure impacts volatility. Total recreation expenditure plummeted following the outbreak of COVID-19 in 2020, leading to considerable declines.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry.
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments. This presents an opportunity for strategic entrance into lower-end markets or unserved markets for innovations to take on a disruptive trajectory.

FAQs.question: What is the industry data table showing?
FAQs.answer: The table shows yearly data for the industry including revenue, IVA (value added), number of establishments and enterprises, employment, exports, and domestic demand from 2005 to 2021.

FAQs.question: What are the column headers in the data table?
FAQs.answer: The column headers are: YEAR, REVENUE ($ MILLION), IVA ($ MILLION), ESTABLISHMENTS (UNITS), ENTERPRISES (UNITS), EMPLOYMENT (UNITS), EXPORTS ($ MILLION), IMPORTS ($ MILLION), WAGES ($ MILLION), DOMESTI DEMAND ($ MILLION).

FAQs.question: What was the number of enterprises in 2015?
FAQs.answer: The number of enterprises in 2015 was 25,356 units.

FAQs.question: What was the value for imports in any year?
FAQs.answer: The value for imports is not provided in the data table for any year.
